user_request: A poem for Valentine's Day about true love lasting forever.

revision_history.draft:
**What Stays**

You taught me that I could say *enough*
and not mean it, and still be allowed
the kitchen sink. October, your left hand
cramping around the mug of weak coffee
you kept holding like a country
carrying its weight in its one good shoulder.
I watched you flatten the crease
in someone else's shirt across the bed,
tucking it inside the collar like a secret.

We had arguments about nothing — I want eggs,
you wanted toast, and instead of splitting
we stood there with our coffee,
faces close enough that I could feel
the brim of your hat shifting on your head.
You said something kind. Not *I'm sorry,*
not *see how silly we are,* just a soft
agreement about the weather,
while you reached behind your back
and adjusted the hat before it touched
your eyes.

Those were the moments I didn't leave.

November came and you forgot
we needed salt at the table.
You brought me the pepper instead
with that particular silence, the kind
that means *I noticed something. I'll make it right.*
But there was no making it right.
There was just a lid of butter on toast,
both our mouths open, both our hands
already reaching for the same thing —
the salt shaker, the coffee cup, the specific
way you hold your mug at three o'clock.

I don't know how long we let that last.
Years, probably. Not because forever
is a thing but because we were both
awful at leaving. You'd go to the window
and press your forehead to glass,
standing so still I could hear
the hinge slowly learning its joint.
I'd sit with my back against the doorframe
and not move — neither of us
doing anything so spectacular
it deserved a name.

The body remembers what the heart
forgets. Your shoulder blade lifting
when you exhaled. The particular
callused spot on your thumb where mine
pressed too hard once and didn't matter.
That's how I know I stayed:
not because of vows or kitchens cleaned
or any version of this we'd sell,
but because my hands kept finding
the exact same place.

And it wasn't easy. You had your days
where you sat on the edge of the couch
with your jacket still on, looking
like someone who just woke up from being
somewhere else, and I didn't fix it.
I'm not saying that right either — what I mean
is I was there with my own particular
lump in me, and we both understood
that's how it looks. Two people
not great at this, sitting in a room
where the clock was ticking its one tall tooth.

That's when love happened — not in declarations,
not in any of those clean things,
but in us failing to get smaller
when being small would have been so easy.
You'd stay in my apartment on New Year's
because you were tired of arguing about who
wasn't trying hard enough. I'd let you.

The body doesn't know the word *forever.*
It just knows the ache of someone
still in your chair when you're asleep,
the thermostat set to whatever temperature
your mouth left on it. That's what stays —
not the way we looked but how we didn't move
from those particular spots, however badly
we sat, however many times
we had to be told not to close the door so hard.

I remember you once cut your hand peeling an apple.
You held it under cold water and didn't cry,
just said *stupid fruit,* and I pressed a towel
to the kitchen faucet until there was enough
and we both stood there with wet hair
and no one fixing anything because
the house looked like itself —
dishes, mail piling on the counter,
your jacket draped over a chair
like it had somewhere to be tomorrow.

That's what I choose: not the version of love
that makes sense on a card. The real one —
the one where we let the faucet run
while the mail sorted itself,
where you said *I know,*
and meaning was enough because
we'd already finished.

And that's how forever showed up:
not in grand gestures but in the particular
way you leaned against the doorframe
with your jacket on, looking at me
like I was a thing you hadn't quite
decided whether to carry inside. I wasn't.
But I held my hands open anyway,
and something — some soft animal
of understanding that had nowhere else to go
— stayed in between us.

That's the only forever I've found:
not the long version but the one
that lives in how we treat a kitchen faucet,
in letting someone sit on the edge of a couch
with their jacket on, in being so tired
of being right that we finally shut up
and let the light do its thing
on whatever fruit was peeling itself.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### What's Alive

The poem is doing real work in its second half. "You taught me that I could say *enough* / and not mean it, and still be allowed / the kitchen sink" — this opening line earns everything that follows because it names a paradox of tenderness: permission without sincerity. The specificity of "the kitchen sink" does what the brief asked for: it grounds love in routine rather than landscape.

The hat scene is one of the strongest passages:

> You brought me the pepper instead
> with that particular silence, the kind
> that means *I noticed something. I'll make it right.*

That "particular silence" does more character work than any declaration could. The body remembers what the heart forgets — this theme gets its best instantiation in "your shoulder blade lifting / when you exhaled." These are images of love as physical habit, and they land because each one is grounded in a single observed moment.

The closing sequence — the jacket draped over a chair like it had somewhere to be tomorrow; the light on whatever fruit was peeling itself — earns its quietness because the poem has built toward it with enough concrete detail. The final gesture (hands held open, "some soft animal / of understanding that had nowhere else to go") doesn't need to name "forever" or declare anything.

The line breaks are doing real work throughout. "I pressed a towel / to the kitchen faucet until there was enough" — that break on "enough" makes the reader feel the exhaustion before the meaning arrives.

### What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / editorializing (lines 53–64).** The passage starting at "That's how I know I stayed:" is where the poem stops trusting its own images and starts explaining them. "Not in declarations, not in any of those clean things" — this is the poet narrating their own argument to the reader instead of letting the accumulated scenes do that work. **Direction:** Cut or radically compress the declaration cluster (lines 53–64). Let "the exact same place" be the ending. Trust the last image.

**Abstraction creeping in (throughout, but especially lines 71–82).** "A soft animal of understanding that had nowhere else to go" — this is a metaphor about a metaphor. "Not great at this" and "we both understood / that's how it looks" are the poem telling us what to feel rather than letting the scene generate feeling. **Direction:** Every time you find yourself naming the emotion (understanding, love, forever), replace it with a concrete physical detail from another moment.

**Cliché proximity (line 79).** "The clock was ticking its one tall tooth" — this is close enough to an idiom that it risks feeling like filler. **Direction:** Either sharpen into something only *this* speaker's clock would

You taught me that I could say *enough*
and not mean it, and still be allowed
the kitchen sink. October, your left hand
cramping around the mug of weak coffee
you kept holding like a country
carrying its weight in its one good shoulder.
I watched you flatten the crease
in someone else's shirt across the bed,
tucking it inside the collar like a secret.

We had arguments about nothing — I want eggs,
you wanted toast, and instead of splitting
we stood there with our coffee,
faces close enough that I could feel
the brim of your hat shifting on your head.
You said something kind. Not *I'm sorry,*
not *see how silly we are,* just a soft
agreement about the weather,
while you reached behind your back
and adjusted the hat before it touched
your eyes.

Those were the moments I didn't leave.

November came and you forgot
we needed salt at the table.
You brought me the pepper instead
with that particular silence, the kind
that means *I noticed something. I'll make it right.*
But there was no making it right.
There was just a lid of butter on toast,
both our mouths open, both our hands
already reaching for the same thing —
the salt shaker, the coffee cup, the specific
way you hold your mug at three o'clock.

I don't know how long we let that last.
Years, probably. Not because forever
is a thing but because we were both
awful at leaving. You'd go to the window
and press your forehead to glass,
standing so still I could hear
the hinge slowly learning its joint.
I'd sit with my back against the doorframe
and not move — neither of us
doing anything so spectacular
it deserved a name.

That's how I know I stayed:
not because of vows or kitchens cleaned
or any version of this we'd sell,
but because my hands kept finding
the exact same place.

The faucet ran in your kitchen.
You left it running. That's what stays —
how the mail sorted itself on the counter,
your jacket draped over a chair
like it had somewhere to be tomorrow.

I remember you once cut your hand peeling an apple.
You held it under cold water and didn't cry,
just said *stupid fruit,* and I pressed a towel
to the kitchen faucet until there was enough
and we both stood there with wet hair
and no one fixing anything because
the house looked like itself —
dishes, mail piling on the counter,
your jacket still hanging, the red dot
on your thumb healing slower than expected.

That's how I know:
not in grand gestures but in the particular
way you leaned against the doorframe
with your jacket on, looking at me
like I was a thing you hadn't quite
decided whether to carry inside. I wasn't.
But I held my hands open anyway,
and something stayed between us —
that soft animal of not-moving,
the one that had nowhere else to go.

That's the only forever I've found:
not the long version but the one
that lives in how we treat a kitchen faucet,
in letting someone sit on the edge of a couch
with their jacket on, in being so tired
of being right that we finally shut up
and let the light do its thing
on whatever fruit was peeling itself.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### What's Alive

The poem is genuinely strong from lines 17–36. "We had arguments about nothing — I want eggs, / you wanted toast" works because it trusts the reader to feel the absurdity and intimacy without being told "this is small." The coffee mug scene ("cramping around the mug of weak coffee / you kept holding like a country") has real specificity — that left hand, that cramping. "You said something kind. Not *I'm sorry,*" — the ellipses and direct speech fragments do what adjectives never would; they let the reader reconstruct the gesture.

The hat adjustment is one of the most alive moments: "you reached behind your back / and adjusted the hat before it touched / your eyes." That tiny, private action carries more feeling than any declaration. The line "I pressed a towel / to the kitchen faucet until there was enough" breaks on "enough" with genuine exhaustion — that's earned detail.

The closing sequence (lines 65–82) is where the poem finally finds its shape: the jacket draped over a chair, the light on peeling fruit. These are images of love as habit and exhaustion, not sentiment. The final gesture ("hands held open") doesn't need to name "understanding" because the reader has been building that word through 27 concrete moments.

### What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / editorializing (lines 53–64).** This is the poem's worst stretch. "Not in declarations, not in any of those clean things" — the poet narrates their own argument to the reader instead of letting the scenes do that work. "The body remembers what the heart forgets" and "not great at leaving" are the poem *telling us* what it means before we've absorbed it. **Direction:** Cut or radically compress this passage entirely. The closing images (lines 65–82) already make these points more powerfully.

**Abstraction (line 71).** "A soft animal of not-moving" — the metaphor about a soft animal that can't go anywhere is doing too much work in too few words and risks feeling like a cliché dressed as original language. **Direction:** Replace with another image or cut entirely; this is where the poem's energy deflates.

**Cliché proximity (line 79).** "The clock was ticking its one tall tooth" — close enough to an idiom that it reads as filler. **Direction:** Either sharpen into something only *this* speaker's clock would do, or cut the line entirely; it doesn't earn its place.

**Redundancy / stacking of similar gestures (lines 37–48).** The salt/shaker, toast/butter, coffee mug at three o'clock — these are all in the same register. Each one is strong individually, but together

You taught me that I could say *enough*
and not mean it, and still be allowed

cramping around the mug of weak coffee
you kept holding like a country
carrying its weight in its one good shoulder.

tucking it inside the collar like a secret.

you wanted toast. We stood there, faces close,
the coffee cooling between us.

reached up behind your back
and adjusted your hat so it didn't shadow your eyes.

Those were the moments I didn't leave.

November came and you forgot

with that particular silence, the kind

But there was no getting it.
There was just a lid of butter on toast,
both our mouths open, both our hands
already reaching for the same thing —
the salt shaker, the coffee mug, the specific
way you hold your mug at three o'clock.

I don't know how long we let that last.
Years, probably. Not because forever
is a thing but because neither of us
was very good at leaving. You'd go to the window
and press your forehead to glass,
standing so still I could hear
the hinge slowly learning its joint.
I'd sit with my back against the doorframe
and not move — neither of us
doing anything so spectacular
it deserved a name.

That's how I knew: not because of vows or kitchens cleaned
or any version of this we'd sell,
but because my hands kept finding
the exact same places.

The faucet ran in your kitchen.
You left it running. That's what stays —
how the mail sorted itself on the counter,
your jacket draped over a chair
like it had somewhere to be tomorrow.

I remember you once cut your hand peeling an apple.
You held it under cold water and didn't cry,
just said *stupid fruit,* and I pressed a towel
to the kitchen faucet until there was enough
and we both stood there with wet hair —
neither of us fixing anything because
the house looked like itself: dishes piling up,
mail sorting, your jacket still hanging,
a red dot on your thumb healing slower than expected.

That's how I knew:
not in grand gestures but in the particular
way you leaned against the doorframe
with your jacket on, looking at me
like I was a thing you hadn't quite decided

But I held my hands open anyway,
and something stayed between us —
that soft animal of not-moving,

That's the only forever I've found:
not in how long it lasted but in how we treated a kitchen faucet,
in letting someone sit on the edge of a couch
with their jacket on, in being so tired
of being right that we finally shut up
and let the light do its thing
on whatever fruit was peeling itself.

revision_history.draft:
October, your left hand
cramping around the mug of weak coffee,
the blue-cloth buttoned open at your wrist.

I watched you flatten the crease
in someone else's shirt across the bed,
tucking it inside the collar like a secret.

We argued about nothing — I want eggs,
you wanted toast. You said *it's October*
and reached up behind your back
to adjust your hat so it didn't shadow your eyes.

Those were the moments I stayed.

You forgot we needed salt at the table.
Brought me pepper instead, holding still
like a fencepost, then: *I'll get it.*
But there was no getting it. The toast,
both mouths open, both hands already reaching —
the exact overlap of two things
that won't divide.

Years, probably. You pressed your forehead
to the window and I sat in the doorframe
with my back against nothing, not moving.
The faucet ran. We left it running.

I remember you cut your hand peeling an apple.
Held it under water without wincing,
said *stupid fruit,* and I pressed a towel
to the kitchen faucet until there was enough
and we both stood there with wet hair —
neither of us fixing anything because
the house looked like itself: dishes piling up,
mail sorted, your jacket on the chair
like it had somewhere to be tomorrow.

You once set your coffee down hard
on a red cabinet and the ceramic cracked
along its seam. Stood there
holding both pieces together
without naming what was broken.

I held my hands open at the table.
Not moving. The light on the fruit peeling itself.

That's how I knew: not in declarations,
not in how long it lasted, but in how you set a glass
down hard enough to crack it
and then kept holding both pieces —
neither of us fixing because
the kitchen looked like ours:
mug still full, salt on the counter,
jacket on, coffee cooling,
a red cabinet, a cracked seam.

final_poem:
October, your left hand
cramping around the mug of weak coffee,
the blue-cloth buttoned open at your wrist.

I watched you flatten the crease
in someone else's shirt across the bed,
tucking it inside the collar like a secret.

We argued about nothing — I want eggs,
you wanted toast. You said *it's October*
and reached up behind your back
to adjust your hat so it didn't shadow your eyes.

Those were the moments I stayed.

You forgot we needed salt at the table.
Brought me pepper instead, holding still
like a fencepost, then: *I'll get it.*
But there was no getting it. The toast,
both mouths open, both hands already reaching —
the exact overlap of two things
that won't divide.

Years, probably. You pressed your forehead
to the window and I sat in the doorframe
with my back against nothing, not moving.
The faucet ran. We left it running.

I remember you cut your hand peeling an apple.
Held it under water without wincing,
said *stupid fruit,* and I pressed a towel
to the kitchen faucet until there was enough
and we both stood there with wet hair —
neither of us fixing anything because
the house looked like itself: dishes piling up,
mail sorted, your jacket on the chair
like it had somewhere to be tomorrow.

You once set your coffee down hard
on a red cabinet and the ceramic cracked
along its seam. Stood there
holding both pieces together
without naming what was broken.

I held my hands open at the table.
Not moving. The light on the fruit peeling itself.

That's how I knew: not in declarations,
not in how long it lasted, but in how you set a glass
down hard enough to crack it
and then kept holding both pieces —
neither of us fixing because
the kitchen looked like ours:
mug still full, salt on the counter,
jacket on, coffee cooling,
a red cabinet, a cracked seam.
